description:
Symptoms: 
The metadata service is not able to serve metadata to VM's. Every time a VM connects to the metadata service I see this error message in the logs:
ERROR nova.api.metadata.handler [-] Failed to get metadata for ip: x.x.x.x
I tried to get metadata from inside the VM by running curl http://<compute-node-ip>:8775/2009-04-04/meta-data/instance-id but got a 404 Error. and the logs on the compute node show the same nova.api.metadata.handler error.

Code:
nova.network.quantumv2.api._get_instance_uuids_by_ip() where quantumv2.get_client(context).list_ports(**search_opts) returns an empty list because quantumclient.v2_0.client.py list_ports() is failing to get the ports.

I think I found the root cause:
In my nova.conf I have the following options set:
quantum_admin_tenant_name= service
quantum_admin_username= quantum
quantum_admin_password= <quantum password>
when an instance is talking to the metadata service it uses a token with these credentials, and based of that token, it gets the tenant-id.
In my case the tenant-id in the token is "service", and the service tenant is not able to see the active ports for tenant "member" which created the instance.
If I change around the credentials in nova.conf to something like:
quantum_admin_tenant_name= member
quantum_admin_username= user1
quantum_admin_password= <user1 password>
then I'm able to get the metadata for the instance. 

Is this a known issue or an issue with my current implementation of Folsom with Quantum?
title: Metadata token issue: Nova + Quantum

comments.content:
Hi,
At the moment there are known problems with the metadata service and namespaces. These are being addressed by the following patches:
Nova:-
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16281/
Quantum:-
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16282/
Devstack:-
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16283/
Can you please try with the abovementioned patches.
Thanks
Gary
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~garyk

comments.content: Those patches are for Grizzly only, but the behavior you describe above SHOULD be working in Folsom, so I'd like to investigate this further.   My best guess is that the 'quantum' service user you created is not an admin user.  Having this users as an admis is required, as it must be able to search across all ports in the system.  See the bottom part of: http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-network/admin/content/keystone.html
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~danwent

comments.content: Thanks Dan... it was, indeed, an issue with the roles. I'm currently using LDAP as the identity backend for keystone and I've used different role/tenant names than the default one (ex, os-admin vs. admin and os-service vs service) It seems like some of the default names are hard coded, but not sure where. As soon as I renamed my role and tenant names to the default ones - it worked! I wish this was better documented...sigh! At any rate - thanks for pointing me in the right direction!
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~kobilaredo
